38.text:
Wuthering Heights is an extraordinarily violent
book and it's there right from the beginning

42.text:
- you know, Lockwood turns up at Wuthering
Heights and these great savage dogs attack

48.text:
him and knock him over and then when he's
brought into the house, they immediately throw

52.text:
a bucket of cold water over him. So that right
from the start, everybody gets caught up in

57.text:
cycles of violence and it's there even among
the children, so the children, when Heathcliff first appears, are really really

64.text:
cruel to
him. So that Cathy, when she asks for a present

69.text:
from her father from Liverpool - she asked
for a whip - what she gets instead of the

73.text:
whip, is Heathcliff. And he has that destructive,
cruel power through the book and at first,

83.text:
it just seems very uninhibited - all the children
are cruel to one another, but also the way

88.text:
they speak to each another, you know - Cathy
says, "I hope he'll flog you sick", she says

94.text:
of Heathcliff and Linton. It gets more controlled
in the second half of the book and whether

101.text:
Heathcliff calculates his violence much more
realistically in a way in the second half

110.text:
and it's something that shocks so many of
the early reviewers of the book. It seems

114.text:
this completely wild, uninhibited book, disgusting,
horrible, violent and that's something I think

122.text:
that readers - since the novel's been written
have responded to and it's something new that

129.text: Emily Brontë brings to the English novel.

133.text:
It's hard to know why Emily Brontë was so
fascinated by violence. I think it's the way

140.text:
that they managed to keep in touch with very
primitive, primal emotions in their childhood

147.text:
and so that they can do the adult controlled
things, as it were, but they know that what

152.text:
lies underneath it can often be much more
uninhibitedly cruel or destructive.

162.text:
So, it's a very violent novel and the first
readers, I think, were shocked and surprised

167.text:
by it and it was, it seemed so different from
the kind of genteel novels that they were

174.text: often used to. So, an early review wrote:

178.text:
‘In Wuthering Heights, the reader is shocked,
disgusted, almost sickened by details of cruelty,

183.text:
inhumanity and the most diabolical hate and
vengeance. And anon come passages of powerful

191.text:
testimony to the supreme power of love, even
over demons and the human form. The women

197.text:
in the book are a strange, fiendish, angelic
nature, tantalizing and terrible and the men

204.text: are indescribable out of the book itself.’

206.text:
In many ways, that's quite a positive review,
but captures really well both how shocking

211.text:
the novel was and the way that it unites apparently,
incompatible qualities - that they're both

217.text: seductive and terrifying at the same time.
